In another thread, I wrote: "The first website I found with an exhaustive list of inventions was: http://www.infoplease.com/ipa/A0004637.html. I counted up all inventions before 1800: there were 84 inventions in the world: 74 were European. Second was China with 3--the crossbow, gunpowder, and paper. India has the spinning wheel and the zero. Mesopotamia has the plow and the wheel. Crete has the flush toilet. Egypt has geometry; and Persia has the windmill."
 
 Can you explain to me why we see a concentration on inventions in European countries?

post_info.post_title: Why so many inventions in Europe?

jim's trucking

In another thread, I wrote: "The first website I found with an exhaustive list of inventions was: http://www.infoplease.com/ipa/A0004637.html. I counted up all inventions before 1800: there were 84 inventions in the world: 74 were European. Second was China with 3--the crossbow, gunpowder, and paper. India has the spinning wheel and the zero. Mesopotamia has the plow and the wheel. Crete has the flush toilet. Egypt has geometry; and Persia has the windmill."
 
 Can you explain to me why we see a concentration on inventions in European countries?

 
 That's interesting. Apparently, Europeans were quite inventive.

That's interesting. Apparently, Europeans were quite inventive.

 They still are, but why so many there, and so few in the rest of the world?
Tastyfish

Climate is good in Europe so there would be a high demand for the land there, there is easy access from most of the largest landmass on the planet so there will be a high movement of people into it bringing new ideas that may stimulate a new invention as well as encouraging competition between people there so both aggresive inventions and ones focused on increasing productivity from smaller sections of land. The wide mix of people there would result in it remaining quite seperate and so the conditions persist. Also once a few inventions have been created then it would encourage more later as more expertise becomes more common around the area and communication improves.
 Just a few guesses anyway.
galton

Climate is good in Europe so there would be a high demand for the land there, there is easy access from most of the largest landmass on the planet so there will be a high movement of people into it bringing new ideas that may stimulate a new invention as well as encouraging competition between people there so both aggresive inventions and ones focused on increasing productivity from smaller sections of land. The wide mix of people there would result in it remaining quite seperate and so the conditions persist. Also once a few inventions have been created then it would encourage more later as more expertise becomes more common around the area and communication improves.
 Just a few guesses anyway.

 Good post. Technological momentum makes perfect sense--once you get going, one invention may lead to another. As for climate, much of Europe is temperate, but so is North America and South Africa. And temperate climates seem pretty harsh to me, especially in the past. They have serious winters, and wouldn't cold weather be an obstacle? I would think the perfect climate would have weather that never gets in the way, like in Southern California. You talk about land (and presumably crop productivity)too, but wouldn't S. California be really good here too? Why didn't the indigenous tribes in that area invent more? 
 
 You might respond that the high movement of lots of people is important along with a favorable climate. Well, Europe is really like a peninsula at the edge of Asia. Your argument tells me the center should be most favorable. China has had crop productivity and large population for a very long time and lots of competetion among different groups (e.g. the incursions of the Mongols), so why not more inventions there? 
 
 Africa is where humans started, so for a long time the population center was there giving that region the only chance of advancement, and there are regions with favorable climates there. If a temperate climate was needed, the Southern corner could have worked just like the western edge of Asia (Europe) did. 
 
 Competition, climate, centrality, and the movement of people is consistent with achievements of the Mediterranean I suppose, but for one thing competition may be the result of achievements as well as the cause. History is replete with examples of cultures that invent something which gives them greater power which they then use to expand and successfully compete with others over territory, etc. Large populations and movements can also be the result of technological innovation. Mesopotamia developed the plow, much more food was produced supporting many more people, and crowding led to movement. 
 
 It seems to me that Mediterranean or China or even Southern Africa may have been the most conducive to scientific achievements based on some or all of the factors you point to, but they did not end up being the center, Europe did.
daewoo

IT could also be that the list is very western. It is missing quite a few pretty major inventions, some of which were important enough that it would be safe to say the world would not have progressed to the point it is at without them. Some examples:
 
 Steel. Earlies known steel items found in syria and india. Still use it today in everything from aircraft to safety pins. 
 
 Sails. Sail power was first invented by the egyptians, and was the primary method of sea travel for the next 2000 years. 
 
 Natural gas. First discovered and used in Baghdad. It was used to light the streets over 2000 years before the village of london first popped up
 
 There were over 10,000 volumes in the library at Alexandria, most of them of a scientific nature, when it was burned by the Christians in the 4th century. The destruction of that library most likely set us back a thousand years or more. Westerners were still burning people at the stake for controversial scientific ideas over 500 years later (such as Giordano Bruno).
 
 A few more that are missing but should really be there:
 
 Domestication of plants
 The hoe
 The sickle
 Domestication of animals
 potters wheel
 fired clay
 glass
 concrete and abstract counting
 writing
 alphabet
 
 
 That is just off the top of my head. While the inventions listed on that page are interesting, you have to take a pretty big leap to say that there was a high concentration of inventions in europe prior to the 1800's. They don't even list the spring, or concrete, or the screw, or metal nails, or the saw blade.
 
 I just thought of and listed 18 more inventions that were pre-1800 and most definatly were not from europe in the 3 minutes it took to type this. I think that citing Europe as a hotbed of invention and technology pre 19th century is a loosing proposition. When the romans invaded germany, rome was already a thriving metropolis, and the germans were still living in thatch huts, sharpening their teeth to points and putting orange clay in their hair.
 
 When Rome was founded, the astronomical observatory in Baghdad had already crumbled to dust and the pyramids were old. WHen trade first started between the middle east and europe, the persians were showing up in ocean going ships, and the europeans were just learning to make plank boats. There were large cities in Africa that the jungle had already covered.
 
 Once Europe finally came out of the dark ages and caught up to the rest of the world, they invented a lot of stuff. This was due to the availability of exploitable natural resources. Europe has/had large deposits of natural resources that they could draw from. They had large stads of good hardwoods. They had large deposits of coal, and large deposits of iron ore. The middle east, Asia, and Africa also have large deposits of such materials, but it is not as easily mined as the Eurpean supplies were. IT was beyond the technology of the time for them to mine their resources efficiently.

 I just thought of and listed 18 more inventions that were pre-1800 and most definatly were not from europe in the 3 minutes it took to type this. I think that citing Europe as a hotbed of invention and technology pre 19th century is a loosing proposition. When the romans invaded germany, rome was already a thriving metropolis, and the germans were still living in thatch huts, sharpening their teeth to points and putting orange clay in their hair.
 
 When Rome was founded, the astronomical observatory in Baghdad had already crumbled to dust and the pyramids were old. WHen trade first started between the middle east and europe, the persians were showing up in ocean going ships, and the europeans were just learning to make plank boats. There were large cities in Africa that the jungle had already covered.
 
 Once Europe finally came out of the dark ages and caught up to the rest of the world, they invented a lot of stuff. This was due to the availability of exploitable natural resources. Europe has/had large deposits of natural resources that they could draw from. They had large stads of good hardwoods. They had large deposits of coal, and large deposits of iron ore. The middle east, Asia, and Africa also have large deposits of such materials, but it is not as easily mined as the Eurpean supplies were. IT was beyond the technology of the time for them to mine their resources efficiently.

 The question was about European dominace overall, not prior to 1800. So are you saying Europe ended up eventually inventing more than other regions or less or what? I suspect you are saying Europe was way behind and only maybe caught up but did not surpass. If so, this is all very good, but it does not address my point. I took a random, long sample of inventions and found that 90% were European although Europe is only a small percentage of the world. Of course, one can find many inventions not listed on that website, but the relevant question is is that list SO systematically biased that it would produce such astonishing results even though the truth is an even distribution throughout the world? You hunt around and can find non-European inventions, but how many European inventions did not make it on the list? The pattern is too striking to explain it away in terms of bias. 
 
 On your natural resouces point, why was steel first developed in India and Syria, if Europe was the place with the accessible resources? And harvesting hardwoods does not require advanced technologies--is Europe is the only place in the world with abundant hardwoods?
 
 My point is that Europe overall has been a hotbed of invention, not just prior to 1800. The sample may have led you to think my focus here is on ancient history--it is not. My sample focused on that early period in response to the claim that Christianity has had less influence in the last couple hundred years. If I had counted all the inventions listed on that website up to the present time, the European dominance would have been only greater. By the way, when I say "European" that means America, Canada, Australia, etc. America alone has been a powerhouse of inventions.

 It is pretty simple to explain it away as biased. When I was talking about "missed" inventions, I was not talking little stuff. I was talking tuff like STEEL. That is a pretty severe oversight. The SAIL, another pretty severe oversight. That list pretty much highlights all the MAJOR european inventions, but leaves out some really major ones from other parts of the world. There is no way you are going to convince me that Europe is responsible for 90% of the innovation the world has seen. They spent too long in the dark ages and were not "civilized" early enough to get in on any early great inventions. They had their time in the limelight, then were surpassed by America and asia (especially japan).
 
 
On your natural resouces point, why was steel first developed in India and Syria, if Europe was the place with the accessible resources? And harvesting hardwoods does not require advanced technologies--is Europe is the only place in the world with abundant hardwoods?

 
 In Syria and India, they were panning iron ore out of the streams or collecting it from open cliff faces. The ore deposts in both places are small, and once the exposed deposits ere used required deep mining operations to get to. By contrast, in europe they were mining the stuff in open pits. Deep shaft mining requires a lot higher degree of technology than open pit mining.
 
 At the time, Europe was pretty much the only place in the known world with abundant hardwoods. The middle east was mostly desert, Africa is a somewhat poor place to get hardwoods (though there are some hardwoods that grow in the jungle, they are difficult to harvest due to the complexities of working in the jungle).
 
 
My point is that Europe overall has been a hotbed of invention, not just prior to 1800. The sample may have led you to think my focus here is on ancient history--it is not. My sample focused on that early period in response to the claim that Christianity has had less influence in the last couple hundred years. If I had counted all the inventions listed on that website up to the present time, the European dominance would have been only greater. By the way, when I say "European" that means America, Canada, Australia, etc. America alone has been a powerhouse of inventions. 
 
 
 Prior to 1800, I think the middle east would beat the wetern world as a hotbed of innovation and scientific learning. I think they would spank us pretty badly. The arabs, indians, and even turks, always held a high degree of respect for science and innovation, while the western world ended up in the dark ages burning scholars at the stake.
 
 Since the 1800's the western world has dominated on the scientific front. While the initial cause of this was most likely an abundance of resources, it seems that there is also a cultural bias that should probably be examined in relation to the question. Even today, there are nomadic people in the middle east who travel around on camels, live in tents, and are perfectly happy to do so. I doubt you would find many westerners who would be willing to live like that, much less "happy to do so". 
 
 The concept of the "gadget" is primarily a wesern invention. Little dohickeys that perform no real function but to entertain or make life more comfortable. You didn't see a whole lot by way of innovations related to comfort or entertainment in other parts of the world, that seems to be a primarily western concern
 
 As time goes by, the west will slowly be replaced as the presumptive world power. History shows us this. Soemthign will eventaully happen that the west will be unable to adapt to (energy shortage comes to mind) and anothe region of the world will become prevelant. While I realise it is difficult to envision anything that could weaken the western world in such a manner, I am sure it would have been difficualt for the romans to belive that their empire would ever fall, or for the egyptians to believe they would someday be surpassed. Yet it happened, and will happen again.

 Once again you are missing my point--the issue is not about the list being incomplete or more important inventions being left off; the issue is whether the sample systematically excludes non-European inventions (or more important inventions that are non-European) and not European inventions to the extent that only systematic bias is needed to explain my results.

 Anatomy, Human
 (De fabrica corporis humani, an illustrated systematic study of the human body) Andreas Vesalius, Belgium, 1543; (comparative: parts of an organism are correlated to the functioning whole) Georges Cuvier, France, 1799-1805.

THis has a lot more to do with our educational system than intentional bias.
 
 
Once again you are missing my point--the issue is not about the list being incomplete or more important inventions being left off; the issue is whether the sample systematically excludes non-European inventions (or more important inventions that are non-European) and not European inventions to the extent that only systematic bias is needed to explain my results. 
 
 
 In that case, yes, this particular sample shows the west as a hotbed of innovation. It is still a poor sample and drawing any type of conclusion from such an obviously limited data set would be impossible. So, the answer to the question:
 
 
Can you explain to me why we see a concentration on inventions in European countries

 
 Would have to be:
 
 There is not enough data presented to propose a hypothesis. 
 
 
Hmmm, "Westerners behaved in such a pathetic, stupid manner here" huh? You are reinforcing my suspicion that YOU have something to prove here. This issue came up in an earlier thread where we were discussing the relative merits and demerits of Christianity. So I got curious about this topic. My point is just what I said: I saw a pattern; how do we explain it?

 
 Nope, no paticular bias and nothing to prove. Westerners DID behave in a pathetic and stupid manner. They burned thousands of years of knowledge in the name of superstition. This, to my mind, is pretty stupid. 
 
 
My point is just what I said: I saw a pattern; how do we explain it?

 
 You saw a pattern based on flawed data. The original sample did not contain enough data to support any kind of hypothesis. THat;s how I explain it.
Eddie

I am not arguing that Europe always dominanted inventing, just overall, so this website is irrelevant.

 
 That depends on how you define "overall". If overall means the most inventions we are currently using or perhaps even the most inventions we are currently aware of I think you may be right that europe, north america and australia is dominating. But is this surprising or even interesting when you consider that the world history of european and american domination in economics, military and technical progress the past 400 years? If we instead define overall as in the longest period of "inventive" (word?) domination Asia looks pretty good...
 
 
 And since when do we suspect that a European would be disinclined to be biased against Europe? Nobody trashes European (or American) culture more than Europeans (or Americans). 

 
 Because we can only write about what we are aware of. And since we are a part of one of the cultures history we are writing about, I wouldn`t be surprised if there was an unintentional bias. Heck, I did a search in Swedish and found many pages listing inventors and inventions and not so surprising they all mentioned Nobel, Celsius and Linnè...
 
 
 The leading quote by Margaret Thatcher shows the guy's agenda:
 
 "Nothing of any significance has ever come from outside
 the English speaking world."

 
 this is true.
galton

No, that means I have been interested in, and studied, history for most of my life. In order to convince me that shis is correct, you are oging to have to convince me that most of the histry I have ever learned is wrong. Prior to the Renaissance, western culture was mainly ruled by superstition. 
 

 Oh yeah, those Classical Greeks and Romans were a superstitious lot. 
 
 

 No, part of the scientific process is ensuring you have good data to begin with. You picked a fairly random web page, counted inventions, and formed a hypothesis. This is NOT the scientific process.
 

 It is undoubtedly a more scientific approach than say anecdote, speculation, and arguing from authority: "My point is right because I read so much." Picking a random website was a virtue on my part. It showed I wasn't trying to find data that suited my hypothesis, unlike yours counter-examples which are motivated to suit your hypothesis. 
 
 
 
 Yes, and I speculate that we see European dominance prior to 1800 because your data set is bad. You asked why I thought the list may be biased, so I told you. 
 

 I asked you about systematic bias sufficient to nullify my finding; you have done no such thing. 
 
 

 If I can list 20 MAJOR inventions of non-european origin that immediatly pop to mind when looking at the list, something is wrong. I am not claiming malice on the part of whoever created the list. I think it is far more likely that it was created by a european who was most familiar with european inventions. If an American made such a list, you would most likely find that it tends to focus on American inventions (unless they hapeed to be a historian, in which case they would be more likely to be aware of other major inventions). THis has a lot more to do with our educational system than intentional bias.
 

 This may have been true 50 years ago, but not today. I spent my education learning about non-European cultures. Apparently, you have read a lot of non-European history, but your criticism remains an anecdotal and speculative one.
 
 

 In that case, yes, this particular sample shows the west as a hotbed of innovation. It is still a poor sample and drawing any type of conclusion from such an obviously limited data set would be impossible. So, the answer to the question:
 
 Would have to be:
 
 There is not enough data presented to propose a hypothesis. 
 
 Nope, no paticular bias and nothing to prove. Westerners DID behave in a pathetic and stupid manner. They burned thousands of years of knowledge in the name of superstition. This, to my mind, is pretty stupid.
 
 
 
 You saw a pattern based on flawed data. The original sample did not contain enough data to support any kind of hypothesis. THat;s how I explain it.

 I picked a period that happened to be BAD for Europe; according to that website, the Europeans did much better in the last 200 years. My study is limited, and a better study may either support it or throw doubt on it, but your anecdote and speculations do not trump my systematic attempt. My conclusion, while tentative, is on more solid ground than your conclusion.
galton

That depends on how you define "overall". If overall means the most inventions we are currently using or perhaps even the most inventions we are currently aware of I think you may be right that europe, north america and australia is dominating. But is this surprising or even interesting when you consider that the world history of european and american domination in economics, military and technical progress the past 400 years? If we instead define overall as in the longest period of "inventive" (word?) domination Asia looks pretty good...
 
 Because we can only write about what we are aware of. And since we are a part of one of the cultures history we are writing about, I wouldn`t be surprised if there was an unintentional bias. Heck, I did a search in Swedish and found many pages listing inventors and inventions and not so surprising they all mentioned Nobel, Celsius and Linnè...
 

 OF COURSE it is "surprising or even interesting when you consider that the world history of european and american domination in economics, military and technical progress the past 400 years?" This dominance you speak of is the VERY thing I am interested in explaining, and haven't even been able to get people to agree has happened in the first place. 
 
 I'd be happy to reframe the debate to "Why European dominance in the last 400 years" if people would agree so as to enable discussion. 
 
 Scholars these days are very aware of other cultures these days because for several decades academia has shifted away from Western Civilization (didn't Berkeley get rid of that as a required course a few years back) and now focuses on non-Western cultures.
Eddie

OF COURSE it is "surprising or even interesting when you consider that the world history of european and american domination in economics, military and technical progress the past 400 years?" This dominance you speak of is the VERY thing I am interested in explaining, and haven't even been able to get people to agree has happened in the first place. 

 
 So what you are really asking about is the reason behind european economic, military and technical dominance the past 400 years? I don`t really see how that would be a "white" trait... It`s probably more concerned with geographic location, natural resources, religous virtues (protestantic virtues creating capital savings- hegel if I`m not misstaken), military aggresion and perhaps even competition (honing and pushing military technologies)... 
 
 

 Scholars these days are very aware of other cultures these days because for several decades academia has shifted away from Western Civilization (didn't Berkeley get rid of that as a required course a few years back) and now focuses on non-Western cultures.

 
 I wouldn`t know. all my history lessons in high school was oriented towards european history and all my university classes has been very centered around swedish, and to a lesser degree european and to an even smaller degree american politics.
galton

So what you are really asking about is the reason behind european economic, military and technical dominance the past 400 years? I don`t really see how that would be a "white" trait... It`s probably more concerned with geographic location, natural resources, religous virtues (protestantic virtues creating capital savings- hegel if I`m not misstaken), military aggresion and perhaps even competition (honing and pushing military technologies)... 
 
 
 
 I wouldn`t know. all my history lessons in high school was oriented towards european history and all my university classes has been very centered around swedish, and to a lesser degree european and to an even smaller degree american politics.

 People are not getting my point. When I say white, I am not arguing that the cause of European dominance is genetic. It appears that our American multicultural ways have not made it to Sweden yet; don't worry, you're not missing much.
 
 The Protestant ethic leading to wealth idea is an interesting one...that is Max Weber. Their worldview was very different than in many cultures. And some technological innovation requires wealth and abundance. But I think part of European wealth came from advances in technology. See my earlier points on this and other arguments you make here.
Eddie

People are not getting my point. When I say white, I am not arguing that the cause of European dominance is genetic. It appears that our American multicultural ways have not made it to Sweden yet; don't worry, you're not missing much.

 
 Well, I think that Hegels theory about the rise of capitalism in northern and central europe caused by protestantic virtues is quite interesting. It could perhaps explain the economic difference between northern and southern europe as well (allthough this took place after the start of the colonial era which probably was extreamly important as well).
galton

Well, I think that Hegels theory about the rise of capitalism in northern and central europe caused by protestantic virtues is quite interesting. It could perhaps explain the economic difference between northern and southern europe as well (allthough this took place after the start of the colonial era which probably was extreamly important as well).

 Right. I updated that earlier post.
billsco

I agree that the Renaissance was an impressive period, but could you explain exactly how the Black Plague would contribute?

 
 Hi galton,
 
 First, I should admit to the folly of reductionist history, as though we can point to X event and say that is the reason for Y event. However, since you've asked for further information I'll try to make my case.
 
 Black Plague, or Bubonic Plague, decimated Europe to such an extent, oftentimes killing every last child in villages, that it caused a reexamination of 
 people's faith in God. The Church was still the most powerful organization in Europe, but this time period can truly be said to have shaken people's faith to the very core. The idea began to blossom that if the human condition could be improved, man himself must improve it. In this way, in my opinion, the Renaissance was born.
 
 That's my story. I'll stick to it, more so than some ideas that wish to make us think it was white European superiority that was responsible for so many inventions.
 
 regards
galton

Hi galton,
 
 First, I should admit to the folly of reductionist history, as though we can point to X event and say that is the reason for Y event. However, since you've asked for further information I'll try to make my case.
 
 Black Plague, or Bubonic Plague, decimated Europe to such an extent, oftentimes killing every last child in villages, that it caused a reexamination of 
 people's faith in God. The Church was still the most powerful organization in Europe, but this time period can truly be said to have shaken people's faith to the very core. The idea began to blossom that if the human condition could be improved, man himself must improve it. In this way, in my opinion, the Renaissance was born.
 
 That's my story. I'll stick to it, more so than some ideas that wish to make us think it was white European superiority that was responsible for so many inventions.
 
 regards

 Neither I nor anyone else in this thread has made a claim of inherent white European superiority. I have been looking for the kinds of ideas you offered, and this one is interesting.
galton

Hi galton,
 
 First, I should admit to the folly of reductionist history, as though we can point to X event and say that is the reason for Y event. However, since you've asked for further information I'll try to make my case.
 
 Black Plague, or Bubonic Plague, decimated Europe to such an extent, oftentimes killing every last child in villages, that it caused a reexamination of 
 people's faith in God. The Church was still the most powerful organization in Europe, but this time period can truly be said to have shaken people's faith to the very core. The idea began to blossom that if the human condition could be improved, man himself must improve it. In this way, in my opinion, the Renaissance was born.
 
 That's my story. I'll stick to it, more so than some ideas that wish to make us think it was white European superiority that was responsible for so many inventions.
 
 regards

 I don't know European history well enough to know if the Bubonic Plague did cause this change in worldview, but something caused a shift leading to the Renaissance, and the timing of the Plague is about right. 
 
 You've got me thinking that adversity could help a society develop. I know that three centers of invention that we have discussed have been Europe, China, and Western Asia. Europe and Western Asia have fairly harsh climates in their own ways, and I think the Chinese were originally a northern people, living in a cold climate. Maybe a fairly harsh climate encourages people to become farsighted, to think, for example, about what can we do now to help ourselves survive the winter? Devoting lots of time and energy to invent things requires an orientation of getting a better pay off down the road even though it may cost you in the short run. 
 
 In milder or easy climates, maybe the pressure was off to innovate; maybe the attitude of "things are good, why change them?" developed. But in climates that were VERY harsh, like with the Eskimoes, two things may be occurring there. Those climates were simply too harsh to survive in, so cultures that live in those climates now simply haven't had as much time in their particular environment as others. And second, if a climate was TOO severe, all energy would be devoted to mere survival; there would be none left over for tinkering and invention.
galton

I wanted to replicate my mini-study of the world distribution of inventions on a different sample, so I picked the next random list of world inventions throughout history up until the present day. This time it was from the Encyclopedia Britannica: http://corporate.britannica.com/press/inventions.html. There were 319 total inventions listed; 291 were invented in European countries, 28 in the rest of the world. That is 91% European, very similar to the number I found earlier. This sample, like the one before, supports the hypothesis of European dominance in inventing.
billsco

You've got me thinking that adversity could help a society develop. 

 
 I agree with that much. Necessity, after all, is the mother of invention. I'm having some trouble digesting the rest your hypothesis, maybe only because of a reluctance to distill history down to that degree. Reductionists, I think, open themselves to indefensible criticisms. At least I would be unable to hold that hill from the opponent's artillery barrage.
galton

I agree with that much. Necessity, after all, is the mother of invention. I'm having some trouble digesting the rest your hypothesis, maybe only because of a reluctance to distill history down to that degree. Reductionists, I think, open themselves to indefensible criticisms. At least I would be unable to hold that hill from the opponent's artillery barrage.

 Well clearly, historical developments are complex and require considering many factors, but the complexity doesn't mean it is impossible to increase our understanding about the causes of these developments.
billsco

Well clearly, historical developments are complex and require considering many factors, but the complexity doesn't mean it is impossible to increase our understanding about the causes of these developments.

 
 All right, then let's see how sound your hypothesis is. 
 
 1. Sounds like the Goldilocks theory. Too cold, too hot, just right. Seems to me if I'm freezing my deal off year after year, I would surely invent a hearth
 at least. 
 
 2. The three centers of invention you mention are Europe, China and West Asia. Yet they also were the ones who wrote the history. Can we be sure we're attributing the right source?
galton

All right, then let's see how sound your hypothesis is. 
 
 1. Sounds like the Goldilocks theory. Too cold, too hot, just right. Seems to me if I'm freezing my deal off year after year, I would surely invent a hearth
 at least. 
 

 Hey, maybe I'll call it that.
 
 

 2. The three centers of invention you mention are Europe, China and West Asia. Yet they also were the ones who wrote the history. Can we be sure we're attributing the right source?

 
 I'm not sure I understand. Are you wondering if they didn't dominate, but just wrote like they did? Well I would ask why did they bother to write things down while others didn't? It's one part of a scholarly culture, no? Along with inventing.
Eddie

Example to bias when it comes to valuing inventions that "lies close to home": http://www.nationmaster.com/graph-T/peo_nob_pri_lau_cap
 
 According to this Iceland (1), Sweden (2), Denmark(4) and Norway(5) are among the 5 most succesful when it comes to nobel price winning discoveries per capita. One could make the assumption that Nordic culture and scandinavian socialistic wellfare states would be the most succesful characteristics when it comes to making groundbreaking discoveries during the 20th century. In fact, the correlation is very convincing. However, when you consider the fact that the Nobel price is a price that is awarded in Sweden and that those who choose the winning discoveries are all swedish citizens with swedish bias the correlation becomes slightly less convincing...
 
 Edit: The correlation is still strong if you choose to examine Nobel prize laureates /GDP (Only that Sweden and Iceland switch places and UK beats Norway) : http://www.nationmaster.com/graph-T/peo_nob_pri_lau_gdp
galton

Example to bias when it comes to valuing inventions that "lies close to home": http://www.nationmaster.com/graph-T/peo_nob_pri_lau_cap
 
 According to this Iceland (1), Sweden (2), Denmark(4) and Norway(5) are among the 5 most succesful when it comes to nobel price winning discoveries per capita. One could make the assumption that Nordic culture and scandinavian socialistic wellfare states would be the most succesful characteristics when it comes to making groundbreaking discoveries during the 20th century. In fact, the correlation is very convincing. However, when you consider the fact that the Nobel price is a price that is awarded in Sweden and that those who choose the winning discoveries are all swedish citizens with swedish bias the correlation becomes slightly less convincing...
 
 Edit: The correlation is still strong if you choose to examine Nobel prize laureates /GDP (Only that Sweden and Iceland switch places and UK beats Norway) : http://www.nationmaster.com/graph-T/peo_nob_pri_lau_gdp

 Interesting, but I already believe any list will have bias. The question is whether there is enough systematic bias to nullify the observed pattern. In my sample there were listed close to 300 European inventions. Roughly 10% of the world's population invented 300 inventions. To believe that, in reality, inventions have been evenly distributed among the whole world, you would have to believe that there were no European inventions missing from the list and that 2,700 non-European inventions were omitted from the list (if 10% invented 300, then 90% must invent nine times Europe--that is 2700). Very unlikely.
Eddie

Interesting, but I already believe any list will have bias. The question is whether there is enough systematic bias to nullify the observed pattern. In my sample there were listed close to 300 European inventions. Roughly 10% of the world's population invented 300 inventions. To believe that, in reality, inventions have been evenly distributed among the whole world, you would have to believe that there were no European inventions missing from the list and that 2,700 non-European inventions were omitted from the list (if 10% invented 300, then 90% must invent nine times Europe--that is 2700). Very unlikely.

 
 Well, first of all I think the numbers of inventions (or discoveries) throughout the history of mankind has been far more numerous than some mere thousands. Secondly, the list is heavily biased as it is only concerned with the time period since the 1800. Thirdly, even lists of older inventions may stand a risk to be biased as the historic recordings may indeed be biased. And fourthly, I think that recent inventions are more likely to both be listed and differentiated and as europe and the US has been dominant for at least 400 years europe and the US will have disaprotionally many inventions listed in a normal list that doesn`t try to answer your particular question.
galton

Well, first of all I think the numbers of inventions (or discoveries) throughout the history of mankind has been far more numerous than some mere thousands. 
 
 My point is about the degree of systematic bias against the non-European. There may be more than 3000 inventions (although your point is speculative) but if there are, it is likely that many European inventions did not make the list.
 
 

 Secondly, the list is heavily biased as it is only concerned with the time period since the 1800. 
 

 Once again your point is speculative; how do we know that many pre-1800 European inventions did not make the list. The fact is that invention were slow in coming for much of human history and have exploded in the last couple hundred years, and most have fallen into the European category.
 
 

 Thirdly, even lists of older inventions may stand a risk to be biased as the historic recordings may indeed be biased. 
 

 Again, speculative.
 
 

 And fourthly, I think that recent inventions are more likely to both be listed and differentiated and as europe and the US has been dominant for at least 400 years europe and the US will have disaprotionally many inventions listed in a normal list that doesn`t try to answer your particular question.

 My question was European dominance in invention overall--not a specific time period--so the list is relevant to this question. Your points as well as the points of every other skeptical person have amounted to mostly speculation and to anecdote. Any reasonable person will take systematic evidence as being weightier evidence than speculation. When I see a better list of inventions show that Europe has had no more than 10% of the world's inventions, then the evidence will have shifted to support for the no-European dominance hypothesis.
Eddie

@ Galton
 
 Regarding speculation in general. 
 This is a debate forum. We do tend to speculate quite wildly in here, we don`t really have the resources, time or even the interest to conduct a scientific inquiry based on methodogical norms. Furthermore, it is your theory. The burden of proof is upon you. 
 
 If you want your theory properly tested you should write a thesis on it. Not post it on a forum...
galton

@ Galton
 
 Regarding speculation in general. 
 This is a debate forum. We do tend to speculate quite wildly in here, we don`t really have the resources, time or even the interest to conduct a scientific inquiry based on methodogical norms. Furthermore, it is your theory. The burden of proof is upon you. 
 
 If you want your theory properly tested you should write a thesis on it. Not post it on a forum...

 The relevant issue is, since we are talking about this, what we should go with in the absence of other information: speculation or systematic evidence? What I have done is not improper, it's just being more thorough than others. You seem to be arguing that when we discuss things, it is better to put as little effort into it as possible, and it is only proper to opinionate without backing anything up. What I have done is basically citing a mini-study, and showing you how the mini-study was done. Since when is it inappropriate to cite evidence? 
 
 The burden of proof is not on me; in a study you have two opposing hypotheses and you decide for the hypothesis supported by the data. The null hypothesis was no European dominance, and the alternative hypothesis was European dominance, and the evidence backed up the latter.
Eddie

The relevant issue is, since we are talking about this, what we should go with in the absence of other information: speculation or systematic evidence? What I have done is not improper, it's just being more thorough than others. You seem to be arguing that when we discuss things, it is better to put as little effort into it as possible, and it is only proper to opinionate without backing anything up.

 
 Nope, I`m arguing that an argument in a forum doesn`t need to be backed up by systematic evidence.
 
 
 
 What I have done is basically citing a mini-study, and showing you how the mini-study was done. Since when is it inappropriate to cite evidence? 
 

 
 Its very appropriate, I would even say prefered, to cite evidence (and I don`t think that I have said otherwise). This doesn`t mean that arguments based on spekulation is pointless...
 
 

 The burden of proof is not on me; in a study you have two opposing hypotheses and you decide for the hypothesis supported by the data. The null hypothesis was no European dominance, and the alternative hypothesis was European dominance, and the evidence backed up the latter.

 
 I don`t have a hypothesis. I haven`t made up my mind about this issue and I have definatly not stated my stance (apart from saying that I find Hegels theory on the connection between protestantic virtues and capital savings interesting). I`m merely questioning your hypothesis.
galton

This doesn`t mean that arguments based on spekulation is pointless...

 I never argued speculation is pointless; I do it all the time in this forum. My point is that speculation is not compelling when weighed up against systematic evidence. Speculation and anecdote, good; systematic evidence, better; very carefully done, full-blown studies, best.

title: 4Forums.com Political Debates and Polls -  Why so many inventions in Europe?
